question: You are a code expert, please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Ensure that the generated code is executable for demonstration. I am a middle school geography teacher and want to help students master the climate types of Asia through a puzzle game. (Temperate monsoon climate-Beijing, Subtropical monsoon climate-Shanghai, Tropical monsoon climate-Mumbai, Tropical rainforest climate-Indonesia, Tropical desert climate-Saudi Arabia, Mediterranean climate-Italy, Temperate continental climate-Xinjiang, Plateau mountain climate-Tibet, Arctic climate-North Pole) Please generate online puzzle game code.

checklist.title: Is the core geography puzzle game mechanic implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code implements the matching mechanism between climate types and their respective geographic locations (Beijing, Shanghai, Mumbai, etc.). Check if all 9 climate types mentioned are included with accurate associations. Score 0 if the core puzzle logic is missing, 5 if basic matching exists but with inaccurate geography information, and 10 if all climate types and locations are correctly implemented with educational validity.

checklist.title: Is the interactive learning mechanism effectively designed?
checklist.description: Assess whether the game includes educational components that help students learn while playing. Check for explanatory text about each climate type, feedback mechanisms that explain why matches are correct/incorrect, and progressive difficulty levels. Deduct 3 points if climate descriptions are missing, 4 points if no educational feedback exists, and 3 points if the learning curve is inappropriate for middle school students. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the geographic visualization component properly implemented?
checklist.description: Review the implementation of geographic visualization (map of Asia, climate zone indicators, location markers). Check if the map accurately represents Asian geography with proper country boundaries and if the climate zones are visually distinguishable. Score 0 if no map visualization exists, 5 if basic visualization exists but with geographic inaccuracies, and 10 if visualization is geographically accurate and educationally valuable.

checklist.title: Is the game state management and scoring system implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate the implementation of game progression tracking, scoring system, and completion metrics. Check for features like progress saving, performance metrics (time taken, accuracy rate), and level progression. Deduct 3 points if no scoring mechanism exists, 4 points if game state isn't preserved between sessions, and 3 points if performance tracking is inadequate for educational assessment. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as incorrect user inputs, browser compatibility issues, touch vs. mouse interactions, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the learning experience (e.g., 1. Climate animation showing seasonal changes 2. Real climate data visualization 3. Interactive quizzes based on puzzle completion 4. Climate comparison tool). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple drag-and-drop systems) 2. Function modules unrelated to geography learning (e.g., unrelated mini-games) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., excessive animations that distract from learning). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core educational functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating game logic/view/data layers), code organization, and maintainability. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if the code lacks comments or documentation for educational content. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet educational design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows educational design principles: 1) Age-appropriate visuals for middle school students 2) Clear information hierarchy with educational content prominently displayed 3) Proper contrast and readability for geographic labels and climate information. Deduct 3 points for cluttered educational content, 5 points for poor readability of critical geography information, and 5 points for visuals that misrepresent climate characteristics. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and suitable for classroom use?
checklist.description: Judge whether the interaction design is appropriate for educational settings: 1) Simple enough for classroom use without extensive training 2) Works on school computers/tablets with potential hardware limitations 3) Provides clear visual and textual feedback for learning reinforcement. Deduct 5 points if interactions are too complex for classroom use, 3 points if performance issues would disrupt learning, and 5 points if educational feedback is delayed or unclear. The full score is 10 points.
